title: When will John Kasich drop out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination?
possible_answers: After the New York primary but before the Nebraska primary
After the Nebraska primary but before the California primary
After the California primary but before the Republican National Convention begins
Not before the Republican National Convention
correct_answer: After the New York primary but before the Nebraska primary
preds: Completely bulldozed by the two questions on the timing of Kasich and Cruz quitting. Will have to be wary of such volatile questions in the future. Still gasping..
Updating for the sake of consistency. I guess Priebus had had enough.

Badda-Bing, Badda-Boom....

Looks like no contested election, as this decision likely allows Trump access to the required 50% of delegates.

Post mortem:  My score will be quite poor on this question because I drastically underestimated the degree to which candidates have to abandon an optimal strategy and fall in line with party thinking at some inflection point.  In the end, this is just my lack of knowledge about the dynamics of primary season. Congratulations to those who got this right.

Would the Rs like at least a token candidate to stay in the race since it provides free press and gives DT even more of a platform to shift toward being "Presidential?"

Updating prediction. Cruz had dropped out, ending any hope of forcing a brokered convention, so Kasich has no reason to stay until the convention. It is however, not uncommon for a candidate with no hope of winning to stay until the end. I'm sure its being discussed if Kasich will drop out as we speak, but if he doesn't drop out now before Nebraska, I can see no reason he would do it between Nebraska and California instead. So I'm raising the pre Nebraska percentage, but still keeping something on the post California  percent.
For now I am going to believe John Kasich's campaign announcement that the Ohio governor has no intention of dropping out of the race.

Kasich is curmudgeonly and stubborn.  But I have to raise this on Cruz' drop out for 2 reasons: 1. Pressure on Kasich (like @Kaizen says), and 2. No longer any purpose to stay in to angle for the VP spot.  And no real reason Trump has to offer a VP spot early either.

The Indiana results and Cruz dropping out means that Trump has a very clear path to the nomination.  Although the most rational strategy is to stay in, the psychological pressure on Kasich will be significant.  Even a poll of Ohioans favors Kasich dropping out, and that was before Indiana's results.

There are plenty of hopeless candidates who have gone all the way to the convention, but they were activist candidates like Jesse Jackson and Ron Paul. They wanted to make a rousing speech and influence the platform. I can't see that Kasich has anything to offer. But without knowing what he's thinking, it's hard to know when he'll drop out. I think the Republican party has written off both Kasich and Cruz by now and is concentrating funds on the Senate races. So does it matter when or if Kasich drops out? No, except financially.

Hard to say. It's looking more likely that Trump will get the nomination on the first ballot, so I'm not sure why Kasich would stay in the race. For that matter, I'm not sure why Cruz would either all the way to the convention. It will cost them a lot to stay in. But promises may have been made to various Republicans. There is the possibility of staying in the race but not campaigning, as Sanders may do on the Democratic side.
Moving Trump chances of earning 1237+ to 48% and 1195+ to 88% based on all the recent polls on the Indiana primary.

similarly to Cruz, I don't see Kasich going anywhere until Trump clinches 1237, and maybe there's an outside chance he doesn't drop out even then, but for the most part it looks highly probable that both he and Cruz will drop out after Trump gets to 1237 in the California primary.
Looks like Cruz will lose Indiana. Not sure where the money will come from for either him or Kasich to stay in. Leads to a very ugly set of estimates. Oh well...
Reversing Conv- and Conv+.  I do not see a reason for Kasich to stay in until the convention if Trump reaches 1237 and that is looking likely.

If Trump sweeps California and wins the 1237 delegates needed to get the nomination before the Convention and the party clearly embraces their de facto candidate, Kasich shouldn't kick and scream, just drop out quietly.

The most important input to my forecasts in the monkey cage challenge has been Trump's chances of getting 1237+ delegates. However, analysing my changes in forecasts so far two things have gone wrong:
	- I have been nowcasting rather than forecasting, ie overreacting to first Colorado and then New York
	- I just assumed 1237 was the hurdle. Taking the first error, I have now looked at every forthcoming primary (mainly based on the tools provided by 538 - http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/), and ended up consequently focusing solely on the races in Indiana and California, there aren't too many margin of error in the others. On the second error, I am making the new assumption that 1195 is better hurdle, as it should be possible for Trump to convince 43 of the unbound delegates (Pennsylvania could provide at least 20) to vote for him. I wouldn't argue if anyone said it was lower but I figured 1180-1210 is the right range. So going back to Indiana, because of its partial binary nature (wta 30 delegates) and its demographics, if it goes to Cruz, which I think it will, Trump may only get 9 votes which would mean he would need around 122 from California. If DT wins Indiana with say 39 delegates, then he would need around 93 from California. All that to say, and sorry for length, but the only way I can objectively remember "what was I thinking" is to write it down, that I have Trump at 42% to win 1195+ delegates, which results in the above change.
What the hell is Kasich trying to achieve? Does anyone have a good explanation???
Kasich will persist until the Convention to try to steal the nomination!

Revising considerably.  I expected him to do better in New York.  He is now likely to come to convention with fewer delegates than Rubio, who quit.  This time nobody will want him for VP, and this sort of performance means he won't be in the running next time either.  These are the main reasons people stick around after it's hopeless.   Because nobody can figure out exactly what he thinks is going on, I'm guessing he won't bail out before convention.  However, if his vote share crashes in the Northeast Regionals next week, he might decide that enough is enough--or rather Not Enough is enough.  He has not previously shown signs of being strange, although he is known to be tenacious.  He may be the oddest subplot in a very odd year.
I think trump has a fair likelihood of getting a majority of delegates some time after CA.

I have TC as 68% likely to stay until RNC, I initially had JK as same probability as TC on the basis that he has the best polling numbers vs HC. However, the more likely it is that DT gets the 1237+ the more likely JK drops out before TC, but not by too much.

Kasich shouldn't expect to win many votes in Nebraska, and thus if he is still in it prior to Nebraska he will stay in after as well. If he doesn't get the support in California he may drop out, but ultimately I think it is more likely he stays involved to the convention.
Kasich appears to want to press against the leading members of the party in order to establish a name for himself in future election cycles.

It seems like Kasich believes that he will be a great president despite his dismal lack of delegates.  I think he is staying in to steal delegates where he can and potentially be nominated at a split convention.
Kasich proclaims he's going all the way but pressure may force him out after NYC.
No reason in my mind why he would drop out before Cruz, if there could be a brokered convention he'll be there - even if Trump just has 1237.

OK so apparently many states have historically treated a campaign suspension as a withdrawal as a presidential candidate, which in some states triggers a freeing of bound candidates. Rubio has taken the approach of suspending his campaign but then specifying that he hasn't withdrawn and would like to keep his bound delegates, please. http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/rubio-makes-unprecedented-bid-keep-delegates-contested-convention-n547646 But I can see how both Kasich and Cruz might want to avoid that ambiguity, and keep thier delegates. And there may even be a few scenarios where they don;t concede even if Trump gets to 1237. I'm now only giving Trump a 15% chance to get over 1237 clear. And I'm giving Kasich a 25% chance he stays in anyway. So .15 *.75 = 11%
Teddy's too big about the "Anybody But Trump" idea.

I think that his race is coming to an end very soon, and it will most likely happen before the New York primary.

Governor Kasich is the Governor of Ohio; where the GOP Convention will be held in July. As such, I submit Governor Kasich will continue to remain a candidate for the GOP nomination. As to the likelihood of Governor Kasich receiving the GOP nomination if a brokered convention were to occur, I might place a 36 percent chance of such an outcome; as the "Favored-Son candidate from Ohio."
I think he's holding out for a contested convention, in his home state.

+15%  For John Kasich to drop out After the New York primary but before the Nebraska primary
Mostly because he is running out of money.
https://www.opensecrets.org/pres16/candidate.php?id=N00009778

Since I don't think Trump or Cruz will get enough delegates to dominate the convention, I have to believe Kasich will still be there. It looks like Trump will do a lot better than Cruz; and Trump is the one the rest want least - which means there is likely to be some rule changing before the convention to make things easier for Kasich.

I base my prediction entirely on the psychology of John Kasich. There is no reason to believe that his performance (or the performance of others) will have any impact on his decision to remain in the race. As it stands now, Kasich still has fewer delegates than Marco Rubio and even came in 4th place behind Rubio in the Arizona primary a week after Rubio suspended his campaign. Kasich has not won any delegates since this became a three-person race. Kasich has continued to underperform in recent primaries. Kasich has little money and organization and has no national campaign apparatus. There is no reason to believe that Kasich's decision to remain in the race or to suspend his campaign is in any way tied to his performance in any primary contest. He has no mathematical path to the nomination, he can only hope for a brokered/contested convention. Kasich foresees that a brokered/contested convention is likely and his control of a election-changing number of delegates will make him very powerful. He will be able to force either Trump or Cruz (more likely Trump) to make him their VP. He is also hoping there is a chance that the so-called "establishment" or Republican party insiders will completely bypass the will of the republican electorate and crown him the nominee, but that is also unlikely.  I think the most likely outcome is there will be a brokered/contested convention and Kasich will join forces with Trump (like he did in Michigan recently) and Trump/Kasich will be the Republican ticket. There are many unknowns, like the yet to be established convention rules, that could greatly impact the likelihood of this outcome, but I think Kasich sticking it out to the very end is almost a certainty.

(no change) My rationale (which I'd be glad to be talked out of) is: JK polls very low in NY. The Rs reluctantly decide to go all-in with TC and do something to encourage JK to drop out (or some status other than actively campaigning). This allows TCs delegate count to go up to bolster the argument that he should be the nominee after the first ballot. (Deals to upset this could still happen, if unlikely. Also, I'm not claiming this is either a good or winning idea, just a plausible approach to manage the chaos.)

I don't think Kasich will recieve enough votes to make himself a viable candidate. If anything, he will just take away voters from Trump. I think that the eastern states will vote for Kasich, so until he has gotten as many votes as he can, he will stay in the election.
He will stay until the RNC unless trump gets the nomination prior.

Kasich understands if he can hang on until moderate voters enter the equation, his chances will be much greater.  The party establishment needs him as the only viable candidate that can beat the Democratic nominee.

He's mathematically eliminated by this point, so his motivation is not purely based on high poll numbers/winning primaries. This means he's most likely accumulating delegates in an attempt to be a power broker at a contested convention or attempting to boost his profile. His biggest barrier to staying in the election will be campaign dollars, which he is starting to run low on.

I don't have anybody close to the Kasich campaign.  My people who have worked with him and/or know him a little bit have no idea what the precise content of his delusions might be.  I think I'll start watching how he walks--the Haldol Shuffle is pretty distinctive. (Having said that and wishing to leave it as is: I have no reason to believe John-Boy is now or ever has been psychotic, or even more delusional than any other Republican, myself included.)

Having updated my Ted Cruz GJP to 93% chance of a contested convention and also updated the Republican candidate of NOTA to be 18%, it would follow logically that apart from scandal/health issues (1%), Kasich will stay in as long as Ted Cruz does. Only issue I see with this logic is if he decides to settle for VP for one of the two other candidates, but why agree to anything before the first ballot takes place?

I don't understand people's predictions here - they seem to be inconsistent with the high predictions for a Donald Trump nomination. The only way DT can get the nomination is to get 1237 pledged delegates. That will happen, if it  happens at all, with the CA primary. I give it a 20% chance of occurring. If DT got 1237, of course the other candidates would drop out, because he would be assured a nomination on the first ballot at the RNC. So if you think DT has a decent chance of nomination, you must also think that Kasich and Cruz have a similar chance of dropping out before the convention!
He's curmudgeonly.  I don't see him quitting unless he makes a deal.

http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/john-kasich-fights-contested-convention/2016/04/10/id/723144/#ixzz45ZEuym00  "We'll have a full court press," he [Kasich] said. "I am the second choice of the Cruz people and also the Trump people. … Also as you know we've had 10 contested conventions, only three times has the front runner won. And I don't want to go back in history too far, but I think old Honest Abe went into the convention third or fourth and came out the winner."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I think that Kasich really intends to go all the way to the convention.  It appears to me that one or the other of the candidates is going to need his delegates, so that will put him in the position of power-broker, if not candidate.
Key recent Cruz victories mean a greater need for Kasich to divert delegates
Based on the interesting link posted by @clinton (Thanks:) http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/09/politics/michigan-republican-delegates-ted-cruz-donald-trump-john-kasich/index.html

He will stick around to see if anybody offers him anything.  Since presumably he knows Clinton will win in November, it's not clear what he would take except the VP nomination; this would set him up as heir apparent for next time. One does not expect this to happen.  You can expect to see him wandering forlornly around the convention hall.
The only reason he remains in the race is to deny Trump the necessary delegates. It does not make sense for him to drop out prior to the convention.
Kasich numerically can't win. However his delegates are of value and he may be able to parlay them into something beneficial such as a vice presidency.

I believe Kasich is remaining in the race as long as Trump does not have the 50% he needs to secure the nomination.  I think there is an idea in his mind that both Kruz and Trump have had such toxic campaigns and are disliked by so many people that he may be the only alternative that could be chosen to the 2 front runners without causing a splitting of the party.  If he goes into a brokered convention with delegates in his pocket then he also has some influence over what is done at the convention.  If Trump wins the nomination before the convention, Kasich will most likely drop out.  Trump cannot accomplish that before California and probably won't get it before the convention at all.

Not changing my percentage, but just pointing out a potential issue: What happens if the rules committee blocks him him from the convention ballot?  My position is that he didn't drop out before the convention so, he still made it.
As the chances of a contested convention go up, I don't think it makes sense for him to go anywhere unless he wants to make an early deal with Trump -- but I am not seeing that.

Kasich thinks he can win over the Trump voter. They just have to learn more about him. After more than 30 contests, and they still prefer Trump to him in all but 1. There's some heavy duty delusion with this guy.

With fundraising becoming harder and harder for Governor Kasich with every passing primary it is in my belief that Donald Trump has a relatively good chance (65%) of clinching the republican nomination before June. In fact he's placed to win at least five of the seven primaries that are occurring this month (April).  If this trend continues and he meets the nomination threshold, Kasich's hopes of a contested convention where he would be crowned the Republican nominee will have but evaporated into smoke.

In The Cat In The Hat, a couple of kids watch helplessly while the house is torn apart, dreading the moment of reckoning when Mom gets home.  In our production, The Kids are played by Governor Kasich, Mom gets home on 8 November, and there is no magical cleanup machine.  Despite a deep and appropriate sense of foreboding, The Kids will loyally stay in the house and be blamed for the mess. Wait and see--in November, the party morons will announce that the entire catastrophe was John-Boy's fault for not dropping out.  No lessons will have been learned, except by The Kids, who will figure out they need to leave home and persuade many or most of their friends to do the same.
With a now nearly inevitable battle of delegates between Cruz and Trump at the convention, it seems likely Kasich will stay in to leverage the power of his pledged delegates.

Giving up and getting closer to the crowd. I still don't understand what drives Kasich and what he hopes for.

After Wisconsin I'm leaning toward the idea that enough R wheels will line up behind TC to give them enough ammunition to "steal" the nomination from DT if the RNC really decides they want to head that direction.

Revised estimate:  Calculation of probability for who/whom will obtain the threshold for the nomination indicates the following:   Even if Cruz takes Wisconsin today (with a majority of its delegates), none of the three remaining candidates are able to meet the threshold, increasing the likelihood of a contested convention.   While Trump is likely increase his delegates numbers on the east and west coasts, it is likely that he will still be short of the threshold.   It seems that a contested convention is in the making.   Waiting for Wisconsin and New York delegate numbers before making definitive decisions about outcomes. Trump could likely still win a reasonable percentage of delegates in Wisconsin, creating a significant hurdle for Cruz.  Estimates indicate that Cruz would have to win 108% of delegates before reaching the threshold, a likely impossibility. Kasich will most likely be squeezed out of the nomination process despite an indication that he might hold on until reaching the convention in Cleveland in July.
looking at polls he will finish last in every single race between Nebraska and California. No body can be that delusional, no matter what they say publicly.

I know he is not doing well in Rep primaries against Trump and Cruz, but why would he quit when he is the only Republican candidate that credibly beats Hillary in the general election? Barring major surprises, both TC and DT loses to HRC big time. I think Kasich's likelihood of leaving the race is remarkably similar to Cruz's. Both are all-in unless there is a pre-convention consolidation behind Trump, which is unlikely (10%) but not impossible.

With Trump looking far from certain to clinch before the convention, Kasich may be gambling on a contested convention to get himself picked. OTOH could he make a deal with Trump (or Cruz) to bow out and be the VP?

He already knows he has no shot at getting the nomination unless it's a brokered convention.  This has been his stance all along.  There is some increased pressure for him to drop out now, but I think he waits at least until after the NY primary since he's already spending much time time there.  There is a small chance he drops out post-California if he feels the sentiment is that he won't get the nomination even if brokered. Other than that, it's hard to guess that a man whose already stated his plan was to be selected at a brokered convention not to keep at it until the convention.

One notes that Barron's thinks everyone should support Kasich.  If there were still telephone booths, everyone who cares about this could fit in one.   I can't make out what he thinks is going to happen, unless he is just trying to suck up Trump voters who hate Cruz equally and might not show up for primaries or caucuses to slow down Trump.  Maybe he just doesn't want to go home--the Ohio Governor's Mansion is hands-down one of the ugliest in the entire United States.

Shifting numbers away from the post-California primary section of this question. With the likelihoood of Trump securing 1,237 delegates prior to the convention decreasing it's a less plausible scenario.
Kasich sincerely believes he is the likely one delegates will turn to if and when Trump does not get the count he needs going into the convention.

This article speaks for me:
Bustle, April 2, 'Will John Kasich Drop Out After Wisconsin? It's Always Been A Long Game For Him': http://www.bustle.com/articles/151648-will-john-kasich-drop-out-after-wisconsin-its-always-been-a-long-game-for-him

Today's Barron's has a cover story about how Kasich would be the best candidate and how unlikely he is to drop out.  Trust me, this cover story has Kasich's attention and that of his advisors. Discusses likelihood of his winning on second or third ballot in Cleveland. Mentions polls showing Kasich as the only Republican candidate who beats Clinton in a head to head matchup, and a Politco website poll of insiders assembled by the site who see Kasich as the most palatable candidate in the event of a contested convention, which today seems even more likely in light of a new poll showing Trump falling 10 points behind Cruz in Wisconsin.  Given the increasingly fervent discussion about Kasich's path, he seems unlikely to pull out even if he runs completely out of money.  I'm increasing the "in it for the long haul" odds to 91%, with surprisingly big delegate wins by Trump as the chief risk to my forecast.
Unless Trump locks it up, he will stay in and hope for a wildcard nomination.
Adjusting to reflect the increased likelihood of a brokered convention.

John-Boy is in an interesting position, although he is not a very interesting guy.  Unless he sweeps the Northeast Regionals, which is unlikely, he will be wandering around with enough delegates to be important only in the case of a very very tight contest at convention; in the meantime he will have run out of money.  He seems to think the party will turn to him in such an event.  This will not happen.  Somebody may offer him a cabinet post, but not an important one and certainly nothing better than his current gig.   Assuming Trump is the nominee and some of the party so-called leaders follow through on their ruminations about putting up someone else as an independent, Kasich might offer himself up as that sacrificial lamb.  Otherwise, he is hardly worth the trouble it takes to ignore him. Considering all that, when if ever he will actually hit the silk is hard to guess out.

The rationale I use here is the same I use for my forecast on when Cruz will drop out. Basically, Cruz and Kasich will only drop out if Trump gets the majority of the delegates. In the case of Kasich the case for a late drop is even stronger because he is stronger in the blue states, that are the majority  in the coming primaries. Below is what I wrote for Ted Cruz, it also applies to Kascsh : "My rationale is the following_ Ted Cruz will only drop out of the race if Trump gets the majority of delegates. So we have to analyze how likely Trump is getting the 1237 delegates he needs to at every stage of the bet. In order to help me with my analysis I go to 538's models  (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/ ). Some notes on this model: - Until now it has been quite accurate in predicting the number of delegates for Donald Trump. 
- The model doesn't predict that Trump will get his majority before California. So my conclusions from the analysis of 538: a) Donald Trump will not get his 1237 delegates before California
b) Even with the errors that may occur in the model it is very likely that Trump will get his delegates before the Convention.   So below follows my forecast: NY- 0%
NEB- 0%
CA- 0%
CONV- 70%
CONV+ 30% Conditions to change my forecast
- Of course, by relying on 538's model I will have to check on how it performs. And review my forecasts accordingly. Further note: sice this forecast is radically oposed to consensus, I challenge everybody to question it. I think my reasoning makes sense and that 538's analysis is solid but would like to hear other opinions. I too was quite surprised that my reasoning led to this conclusions :) :) :)  "

Moving 5% from 4th to 3rd bucket. Still don't think it likely but California will be expensive to have any presence in and once that batch of primaries is over there is no reason to not to continue to go into the convention with whatever he has accumulated.

I love this question. I've been thinking about it a lot lately. As of 3/29/16, many top operatives and Kasich himself believe that he has the best chance of Republicans in the general election. In order for Trump to win on the first ballot, he would need in excess of 55% of the remaining delegates, which is highly improbable given his rising unfavorable ratings in polls since the primaries began and his recent attacks on Cruz' wife.  If Trump does not win on the first ballot, the delegates are free to switch to another candidate. Top party operatives seem crystal-clear on this scenario as does Kasich.  The only reason I'm not 90% is that Kasich says he won't drop out "before Wisconsin".  I'm concerned that he's not stating more confidence about hanging in there than that statement implies. His motivation for staying in is exceedingly high. Dropping out before the convention would be a baffling move that would throw the party into a state of near despair.  It's certainly not impossible, and money may determine the outcome, but it would go down as one of the great fumbles in American political history.

http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/03/28/john-kasich-switches-things-up-wisconsin/82345930/  " . . . [Kasich] hopes his moderate stances and milder campaign style will have a stronger appeal in states in the eastern part of the country that vote in mid- to late-April, such as Pennsylvania. So the campaign is canceling some ads in Wisconsin, placing new buys in promising congressional districts and is saving more money to spend in East Coast states.

Not many people in Ohio seem to wish for him to come back and be governor. He's in until the money dries up, and maybe longer.  John-Boy is nowhere near as daft as, say, Kindly Doc Carson, but his contact with reality may be as tenuous.  This is a non-trivial distinction, but in this case it has no policy implications.

with polls showing him beating Clinton, it makes it more likely he stays in until the convention. But he may well not get any delegates before the convention and he will likely be broke. I still see this as grandstanding, and if polls showed him losing to Hillary he might be out already, but have to give him some benefit of my doubt.

It is unlikely that the GOP will try to get John Kasich to win the majority over Trump, so he will drop out shortly before or at the 2016 Republican National Convention. It would be strategically unsound to drop out before the California primary, because it could result in a loss of delegates.

It is unlikely that the GOP will try to get John Kasich to win the majority over Trump, so he will drop out before the 2016 Republican National Convention and endorse Ted Cruz at that point. It would be strategically unsound to drop out before the California primary, because it could result in a loss of delegates.
Kasich will need to see that he is getting "some" votes along the way, AND that DT has not reached 1,237 delegates.

He will only drop if Trump gets the necessary delegates after California

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/24/us/politics/john-kasich-rejects-a-gop-call-to-quit-to-block-donald-trump.html?emc=edit_th_20160324&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 "Republicans desperate to stop Donald J. Trump from capturing the presidential nomination increased the pressure Wednesday on Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to quit the race . . .  "Mr. Kasich refused, saying that he, not the Texas senator, was the best option to stop Mr. Trump . . ."Mr. Kasich ignored all calls to step down. He campaigned Wednesday in Wisconsin, where the next Republican primary will be held April 5, and his advisers argued that the race’s final stretch of 20 states, mostly in the Northeast, Middle Atlantic and the West Coast, put Mr. Kasich in a far stronger position than Mr. Cruz to halt Mr. Trump.
“When we get to Pennsylvania, we get to New Jersey, Connecticut, Rhode Island — let me tell you, I drop out, Donald Trump is absolutely going to be the nominee,” Mr. Kasich said. “I don’t believe that Senator Cruz can come to the East and win.” "Charlie Black, a strategic adviser for Mr. Kasich, echoed the theme, stressing that moderate Republicans dominate in most of the remaining states, not those who identify as “very conservative” or evangelical, who have been Mr. Cruz’s base of support.
. . . 
". . .  His strategy is to emerge as a white knight at the national convention, under the assumption that Mr. Trump will arrive in Cleveland lacking enough delegates for a first-ballot nomination.
. . . 
"Despite his huge deficiency, the Kasich campaign, citing national polls, argues that he would be the only Republican nominee with a chance of winning the White House in November. A poll this week by The New York Times and CBS News showed Mr. Trump losing a general election contest to Hillary Clinton by 10 points, with Mr. Cruz falling behind Mrs. Clinton by a narrower margin, but Mr. Kasich holding an advantage over her. "Strategists for Mr. Kasich argue that having two challengers to Mr. Trump will deny him more delegates in more places, especially states where most delegates are allocated based on congressional districts. These include Wisconsin, New York and California, whose trove of 172 delegates is the largest of any state. "That claim is “empirically false,” said Chris Wilson, a pollster for Mr. Cruz. “The fact is, Trump has a ceiling that is demonstrated election after election. All John Kasich does is split the anti-Trump vote, thereby handing Trump a plurality in each of these states.”
. . . 
"All three candidates are looking to Wisconsin, where Mr. Kasich hopes to appeal in a Midwest industrial state similar to Ohio. An analysis of polling data by The Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel recently showed Mr. Trump was highly unpopular in suburban counties near Milwaukee, which are some of the most favorable districts in the country for Republicans. But Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, has signaled that he favors Mr. Cruz.
. . . 
"A problem for Mr. Kasich in emerging as the nominee at a contested convention is that current rules require candidates to win a majority of delegates from eight states to be on the ballot in Cleveland. Although that can theoretically be relaxed by the rules committee, delegates loyal to Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz on the committee, likely to be in the majority, could block changes favorable to Mr. Kasich. "So desperate are some Republican leaders to stop Mr. Trump, believing he would lose the White House and threaten the party’s grip on Congress, that they have urged Mr. Cruz and Mr. Kasich to coordinate efforts. The Ohio governor, say, might concentrate on districts in liberal Northern California, with the Texas senator focusing on more conservative Southern California.  But there is probably too much bad blood between Mr. Cruz and Mr. Kasich for that kind of détente. Mr. Cruz was furious that Mr. Kasich campaigned in Utah. Mr. Kasich is angry at Mr. Cruz’s continual refrain that he is a spoiler and should quit.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Kasich has been resisting pressure to drop out since almost the beginning.  Since Kasich & team are still saying these things even after he got only half as many votes as a guy no longer in the race, I'm thinking he is going to hang in there until he is broke.
John Kasich would prefer to see a contested convention and believes he is the most qualified candidate still in the race.
I believe him, like Bernie Sanders will want to stay in the race.
He's not making sufficient headway in the polls. If this continues, people will turn on him at some point so that Cruz's chances improve.

If he were merely interested in winning, he would've dropped on by now. It looks like he's still in just to take votes away from Trump. If Trump manages to get the golden 1237 delegates, then there's no reason to stay on after California. Per fivethirtyeight, Trumps not far off target. http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/republicans/

Kasich’s campaign . . . .is dug in. His chief strategist John Weaver issued a memo Tuesday calling Kasich “the key” to stopping Trump and arguing both Cruz and Trump “would lose to Hillary Clinton in dramatic fashion.” http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/trump-cruz-kasich-western-primaries-221114#ixzz43l1uqMPh

COMMENT:  Of course Kasich's campaign is going to make such claims!  What candidate ever announces a plan to quit at some future date?  His dismal results yesterday (half of Rubio! who's not even in the race anymore!) has got to be causing the Kasich team to do some soul-searching.

It is hard to fathom what John-Boy thinks might happen. He is running out of money, and he never had many friends, even (or perhaps especially) in Ohio. No matter how deadlocked the convention is, they will not be turning to him, except to ask him if he'd please take one for the team as the VP loser.  If offered this, he might take it--he has a secure job as governor of Ohio until '18, and apparently doesn't mind letting the state run itself more or less indefinitely. If he doesn't win Wisconsin, which is not on the cards, he will need to sweep the Northeast Regionals, which is also increasingly improbable since he is running at decimal-dust levels in at least New York and Pennsylvania. He will come third and possibly even fourth in California, so he is likely to come into convention with fewer delegates than Rubio, who has already hit the silk.  So the big question is when reality will attract his attention and that of his funders if any. My guess is his backers will pull the plug after California, but he may decide to beaver on using his credit cards and home mortgage until convention.  My recollection from working with him is he is a bit of a slow learner.

Based on: 
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2016/03/22/after_arizona_utah_voters_to_get_primary_break___130044.html "For his part, Kasich isn't willing to play along with his rival and is instead aiming to peel away as many delegates as he can to get in hopes of competing at an open convention in his home state this July. "I'm going to compete across the country and tell people who I am and let the chips fall where they may," he said on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” "And let me also tell you, no one – no one -- is going to that convention with enough delegates."  I don't think Kasich will get out unless he runs out of money.

The thing about Kasich is that he's running a campaign on almost no money. When he says "We'll get a covered wagon and go into the western states" he means it literally, because he can't afford a tank of gas. Yet, he's able to stay around mostly by doing multiple town halls per day where he riffs off the top of his head. Given the recent effectiveness political tv advertising, the cheap town hall strategy seems like it might work well enough to keep him around for a long time. But all campaigns run out of money eventually, even if just for transportation and basic staff. Kasich is going to have to pick a spot and go all in, and then start planning to be Donald Trump's VP (*shudder*). I'm thinking it will be Wisconsin on April 5th. It's in the middle north, his only strong area and carries a relatively large number of delegates. If he doesn't place at least second there, he'll have to bow out. I don't think he'll make it. By that time the Stop Trump movement will be very desperate, and they'll either rally around Ted Cruz (*shudder*) or continue dreaming about a third party candidate / convention nuclear option. Trump has such a lead in New York (+52 as of March 18th) that it just won't make sense for Kasich to continue burning money.
Four weeks till NY. Zeroing that bin was a mistake. Lots of time for him to realize how  silly it is.
Kasich just got half as many votes percentage-wise in Idaho as Rubio, who is no longer in the race.

Affirming forecast but it's too funny not to mention: in AZ today, the most electable Kasich took forth place in a race that only has three candidates: http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/primaries/AZ (Rubio is well ahead of Kasich!)

Changed this due to upping Trump's chances of a clear 1237 to 25%. I also think that in the 40% likely case that Trump gets 1200+, there's about a 30% chance that Kasich cuts a deal for a VP slot. And a 10% chance that Kasich cuts a deal with Trump getting him over 1237, even if Trump has less than 1200 delegates (which I put at 35%).  So chance that Kasich drops out between CA and the RNC == chance Trump gets to 1237 clear, or gets to 1237 via a deal with Kasich = .25 + .4 * .3 + .35 * .1 = 40.5%

Great question.  I have no idea what Kasich thinks he's doing.  The chance of a contested convention won by Kasich is slim, and by campaigning in Utah he's actually reducing the chances of a contested convention.  He's either trying for Trump's VP or waiting to run out of money.
There seems to be little incentive to drop out. He will have influence at the convention. But, if he were to drop out, it would be after losing in big states.

I thought I posted this earlier, but apparently I mashed the wrong button and made it disappear instead:  John-Boy would like Wisconsin but won't quit if he loses there.  He must do very well in the Northeast Regionals (New York to Rhode Island, 18-26 April), or he'll need to quit, especially if he's lost Wisconsin.  Depending on how all that goes, he could pick up some delegates in Oregon and Washington since they're not winner-take-all.  California is just strange every year, and could bump him hard in either direction.   If he is approaching convention with 450-500 delegates he'll stick around to see what happens next.  Much below that he's not interesting to the others, who will most likely prefer to see what they can do with Rubio's delegates and the other strays first.  In the absence of a firm deal he won't win on second or subsequent ballots either, as he leans too grownup for most of those who will be voting and the party elders are busy throwing our principles overboard to stop the ship sinking (it won't work).   So the punchline is he should probably quit now or quite soon, but he probably won't.

Currently giving Trump a 15% chance of getting to 1237 with California. Adding another 20%points for the chance that dealings between CA and RNC (eg cutting a deal with Trump) leads to Kasich dropping out. Adopting @roreiy 's logic for the rest, but dialing down the chances for him withdrawing before NY.

As with Cruz, there's no case for Kasich to drop out prior to New York. 
Unlike Cruz, though, there may be a case for Kasich to drop out prior to New York. For example, if the race in California were to narrow to a two-way race between Trump and Cruz, with Trump holding a narrow plurality and Kasich in a distant third but with enough votes to sway the outcome, it may emerge that Kasich's best shot at winning the nomination would come by ceding California to ensure a brokered convention. 
However, it seems more likely that in this case Kasich would make certain strategic moves (as Rubio did in Ohio) to push his delegates to Cruz without dropping off the ballot entirely.
His post-California scenario is identical to Cruz's: If Trump has the nomination sown up, it's all over; if not he goes to the convention.
I believe John, as Ted...are going to see how long they can stay in...play it by ear longing for a Brokered Convention.
Since he won Ohio I expect he will go all the way to Cleveland,   The only change would be if Trump collects sufficient delegate votes to win on the first ballot
Recent declarations from Kasich make it seem like he wants to play a brokered convention; however, it may seem unfeasible after NY.

".....the upcoming proportional-delegate primaries for Republicans include California, Connecticut, Nebraska, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Utah, Washington, and West Virginia."

I think he is going to take it as far as he can. There are several moderate conservative states left on the map. And many of them are proportional allocation of delegates. There are still 30 states left to vote (as of 3/21).

Kasich has vowed to stay til the cows come home, but after the California primary he may let stubbornness fall by the wayside and concede the likely hood of nomination.  If, and it is a big if,  he may hope for a convention nomination.

April 19 is a LONG way off and he likely will win zero states before then. He began the month with very little cash, only 1.3m at the beginning of March. a logical person would already be out, and i think he may be gone on Wednesday this week.

I think the remaining candidates will likely push all the way to the end, if only in the hopes of influencing the conversation. If Trump gets closer to winning the majority of delegates, I'll revisit.

He won Ohio.  Chances of him doing well in his "best" states and Cruz doing well in Cruz's "best" states are better than 50/50 (my perspective).  Probably a solid Trump win in Arizona, but Trump won't consolidate support smoothly.  Expect bumps.

Kasich is not getting funding from the establishment. He will hold on until Pennsylvania; possibly withdraw after PA or Indiana when he runs out of money, or if Trump has it locked up. Or hold on til Oregon or Washington. I think it unlikely he holds out until the convention unless there is a deal to deny Trump.

His only chance would be if Trump doesn't reach the required number of delegates (1,237) by the date of the convention.   Since the last of the primaries occurs June 7th (California with the most delegates this date) if Trump has the required delegates after that Kasich will then drop out.

Kasich is a reasonable man with a life, who has lasted in the field by virtue of winnowing candidates. So far he has, somewhat reasonably, assumed the dropout's committed delegates would swing his way. However in a field with the intractable Cruz and Trump he will soon realize his chances of winning the nomination approach zero where Rubio, et al aren't present to take the heat. It will take him two cycles to fully recognise this fact, after which his rationality will compel him to drop out.
He's hoping for a miracle (and so it the GOP)
Unlike some Kasich can be taken at his word. Trump will be the nominee, but Kasich will eventually earn Trumps respect and be part of the administration.

On Meet the Press, Kasich made it clear that he will hold the line no matter what. However, other Republicans could convince Kasich to drop out before the convention IF there is a strategy to nominate Ryan or another non-Trump candidate. If the Republicans do nominate Trump, I do not see a way forward for the party. Therefore, the GOP leadership must find a way to NOT nominate Trump.

Of the three remaining candidates, he is by far the preferred choice of the GOP administration and he will have their full backing. Trump requires over 50% of the remaining votes, but appears to have a high water mark around 40-45%, on that showing he won't get automatic selection. Both Trump and Cruz are disliked by the administration. Kasich with Rubio as VP is a well anticipated combination.
John Kasich has ballot access problems
this guy really believes he should be the next president and can make it at the convention.

The Convention, if it can, are choosing someone else than Mr. Trump and Governer Kasich believe he is one of the best fitted candidates to beat Mrs. Clinton.
The Convention can end up believing that too.
In  3 way race in CA he has a decent chance  of winning CA.
As long as Trump doesn't have the in inaction locked up, he will stay in.
I believe he will use his position to extract as much as possible for his own personal gain from either Trump or Cruz and the longer he stays in the higher his "stock" will be.
Other than Trump and Cruz, no one in the Party will ask or want him to drop out

Before the NY primary, there are 3 republican contests: AZ, UT, WI. In order for Kasich to stay in the race, I think he must win Wisconsin to make his case that he can stop Trump from amassing a majority of delegates. That said, there is no recent polling of WI - the last poll (2/18-2/21) included Carson, Rubio and Bush (http://fox6now.com/2016/02/25/new-marquette-university-law-school-poll/). Let's assume the race is a toss-up between Trump and Kasich in WI. Losing all 3 primaries before NY will likely entail the end of the Kasich campaign (though there is always a chance he somehow convinces himself to stay in). I therefore estimate his chances of dropping out before NY as 40%. Next up comes NY, CT, DE, MD, PA, RI, IN. These states heavily favor Trump. Presuming Kasich is still in the race, he is likely to be left without winning many delegates in this section. I estimate his chances of dropping out at 40%. If he somehow manages to stay in the race until the Nebraska primary, I think it is likely he stays in until the convention. There would only be one more month of primaries, he would have likely won a handful of states, and also be in good position to deny Trump a majority of delegates.

Kasich is likely to do best in states that vote later, and his strategy is to present himself as an alternative to the "outsider" candidates Trump and Cruz. That strategy hasn't been working well recently, but a win in NY, NJ and CA could make that more presentable. He could also have some leverage at the convention by remaining in the race and controlling delegates. The wild card here is that he might be convinced to support a "stop Trump" movement, and by leaving the race, it might help Cruz stop Trump. Not sure how much love there is between Cruz and Kasich, and it isn't clear how much dropping out helps Cruz in the later races.
he will only drop if Trump gets the number

He's not running a strategic campaign. He's trying to win as much as he can, regardless of how it likely helps Trump(UT).  Game theory not in his plan. He is hopping for lots of help from the voters; even more from the RNC rules committee. When he gets the hint the voters don't want him, is a big guess. The trend outside of his home state has been mostly big loses. I expect that to continue.  Hard to predict when a mule will move. Beating him like a rented one, only seems to make him more stubborn.

If the convention is not contested, Kasich will almost certainly drop out before the convention.  According to PredictIt, there is a 60% chance that the convention will not be contested ([1]).  Kasich is very likely to stay around for a contested convention, which is precisely the situation in which he has highest leverage, so I'm giving a 35% chance to CONV+. Other scenarios:
- Kasich could leave after being offered the VP slot by Trump.  This could happen at any time, including before the New York Primary.  PredictIt gives Kasich a 17% chance of being VP, so I'll say that he has a 15% chance of being Trump's VP, and distribute that among all of the possibilities except CONV+.
- Kasich could leave because he realizes he can't win.  This is probably most likely after the New York or Pennsylvania primaries (in time period NEB-), so I'll that period an additional 25% chance.
- Kasich could leave after Trump wins the majority of delegates.  This is most likely after the California primary, so I'll give CONV- the remainder of the probability weight. [1] https://www.predictit.org/Market/1529/Who-will-win-the-2016-Republican-vice-presidential-nomination

I heard an interesting discussion on one of the talking heads shows that makes sense to me and changes my predictions on Kasich (who I am a fan of and voted for here in Ohio, full disclosure). He is betting on his appeal in the Mid-West.  Wisconsin is the only remaining  Mid-West state left in the race in a short time frame (Indiana and Nebraska are in May---too far out in my opinion).  If he does not win that one (he MUST win that one to be considered AT LEAST a small chance at the Convention as the alternative who can win the important Mid-West), he will lose all momentum (meaning money!) and the "establishment" will throw in the towel and go all-in for Cruz (not their preference, but...).  This pundit suggested that from "his sources" that Kasich will decide after Wisconsin to make a deal with Cruz or not. Take this all with a grain of salt, but Kasich IS a smart guy and if he can't win Wisconsin then even with his ambition I think he will see the writing on the wall. Seems to me "Before New York" should be in play more than it is (at a higher risk, though), "After New York but before Nebraska" out of play, and "After Nebraska but before California" should be more in play. However, if he loses Wisconsin and does not quit after Wisconsin, then he would stay in through "Nebraska" because that would include Indiana as well---Mid-West states.  He would not quit after New York because he will not do well there anyway. Bottom line: If he does not win Wisconsin, then he can write off Indiana and Nebraska too.  That is his whole strategy and he loses all moral claim to claim any legitimacy.  So, I think Wisconsin is more important than we may think it is. Kasich may want to be VP, but absolutely not for Trump. But I can see him consider to be Cruz's VP.   That is where the dealing may come in. Just my thoughts upon hearing this analysis.  Not trying to influence anyone.  Thanks for reading.
This guy is a magical thinker, in so many ways. As with magical thinkers, it's hard to tell if they are lying to you, themselves or both.

I don't see any reason Kasich would drop out before New York, as those are not states where he expects to do well. He needs to do well in Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, and Pennsylvania. If he can't get votes there, he won't get them anywhere. If he doesn't, he may drop out. The only state where he has much chance between Nebraska and California is Oregon, so there won't be much motive to drop out at that point. If he does poorly in California, he'll have a big problem, so he might drop out there. He might go as far as the convention, but it may depend on how well Cruz does and if the party is still ignoring him.

CA is everything for Kasich. Polls show him doing well up until then and closing gap on Cruz/Trump so his narrative in national media will be good. No reason to drop out before CA unless scandal/death/illness get in way. CA is meal ticket for him, if he competes with Trump he should go to contested convention and represent establsihment candidate with national appeal or at the least further his post candidate career. If he does poorly in CA, where Trump is leading polls, he might drop out due to funding issues.

- Kasich is slightly delusional because even in the beginning when no one knew who he was debate after debate and he was at the bottom he refused to drop out. There were still decent candidates left. Now that there aren't any decent candidates left, I don't see any reason why he would drop out. He should have dropped out when Jindal dropped out. If he didn't do it then, he's not gonna do it now. There could be a massive shift. People may realize that Trump and Cruz are crazy. Then it may shift to him. 
- Question: what is the technical meaning of a "drop-out". Is that voluntary or also involuntary (i.e. Trump gets enough delegates to win the nomination before the convention)?

That's a real head-scratcher. What exactly does Kasich want? If he ends up being nominated despite coming third in the primaries, does he expect to still win the election? That is, all the GOP voters that he and the party snubbed are going to come out and vote for him? Someone's got to be very stupid here - and it's either Kasich or the voters. Or is he just after the thrill? Like a gambler that cannot quit? Or, is he a secret Trump agent? All the logic says that the longer he stays, the more he helps Trump.  Ugh, probably going against the consensus here but I just don't see him to not drop out at all.

JK will most likely be gone if he has poor showings in Arizona and Wisconsin (both before NY). If still in for NY likely to drop out soon after if (as I expect he will) he gets heavily beaten by DT in NY. 
If he is still in at that stage, he must be targeting the convention (irrespective of delegate count), but could potentially run out of funding.

He said he would not drop out prior to the convention, and it is his persona to say what he means and mean what he says.  So believe him on that score.  And there are a lot of forces at play here.  It seems crazy to just drop out prior to the big show if he has a meaningful number of delegates.   The only thing I can think of is if Cruz and Trump consolidate.  Then he might just give up.

"Insiders: Kasich could win a contested convention POLITICO Caucus members say the Ohio governor would be more acceptable to GOP delegates than Ted Cruz or Donald Trump." - http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/john-kasich-contested-convention-insiders-220946#ixzz43I9z3hGq ------ I am not saying that he will win. I am just saying that he might stick around to find out. Of course, depending on the rules, he might also get out of the race earlier and still come back at the convention. However, given the interest in stopping Trump, I assume he will stay in. If he is up for Trumps VP-spot, he will drop out of course.

At this point, he's already mathematically eliminated; winning every single delegate from here on out would not get him a majority.  So, I can't think of any event at this point that would actually give him a reason to drop out.
With the  convention in Cleveland, Kasich wants  to be the home state darling through the casting vote.

I'm stumped on all GOP questions at the moment really. I think the whole process will go down to the wire, and it is unlikely Trump will hit 50% before California, given how many delegates are given out on that final day. Kasich could be maybe persuaded to drop out of the race at this early point by people like Romney https://www.facebook.com/mittromney/posts/10153370698696121 arguing he only makes Trump more likely, but I don't think this is the game Kasich is playing anyway. If he performs very poorly in NY, Penn, Connecticut he may have to cease his campaign, but I think he will do well enough to keep dragging along. If he hits Nebraska, there is no expectation of anything before California, so he would be very unlikely to drop out over that month. He may, however run out of money. I suspect he wants to trade his delegates for a VP spot, but I'm not sure if he would do this after California (when a contested convention would become clear), or at the convention itself. If Trump gets enough delegates after California, it seems very unlikely Kasich wouldn't suspend his campaign, it would be a total waste of money and effort. Since there's probably a 50:50 chance of Trump doing this, Kasich must have a less than 50% chance of reaching the convention, since there is also a chance that there is a contested convention between only Trump and Cruz.
Only a deal with Trump will take him out before the convention.

This is a tricky one. I think it depends on what his goals are. It's likely that him staying in the race will decrease the odds of Trump hitting 50% of the delegates, so he may stay to 1) play spoiler for Trump 2a) increase the odds of a brokered convention and 2b) his odds of being chosen as a consensus candidate  and 3) increase his odds of being a VP.  If he wants the VP slot on a Trump ticket, he may have to pull out before the convention. If he wants to get in Trump's way (assuming it is mathematically possible) or to gamble on getting the P nomination he'll stick it through.  Tricky.

John-Boy will almost surely stay in, no matter how hopeless, for--oddly enough--the same reasons that Sanders will stay in the D game:  He will feel the need to keep his message alive.  Kasich's message is less specific than Bernie's, consisting as it does exclusively of "let's go with a grownup," although the Guv just barely qualifies in that category.   Unlike Cruz, he is not likely to be offered any blandishments for the Jump to Trump, and if offered is not likely to accept them.  He is not exactly a tree full of owls when it comes to smarts, but he does have some principles.  So far.
First guess: GOP need both Kasich and Cruz to minimize the number of delegates that DT wins.

Kasich's big risk is running out of money. He will not have a majority of delegates before the convention under any possible scenario. I think he's in for the duration unless Trump hits a significant majority before the convention, OR Kasich runs out of money.
Not while Trump still has a shot and GOP establishment centrists are looking to back a dark horse.
